questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with numbness and tingling in the lateral aspect of his forearm and thumb after a fall. Upon examination, the physician notes that the sensation is decreased in a specific area corresponding to a dermatome. Which of the following dermatomes is likely affected in this patient?

A newborn is delivered with a shoulder dystocia complication. On examination, the infant has paralysis of the arm with the shoulder adducted, the elbow extended, and the forearm pronated. This injury most likely involves which of the following structures?

options.label: A
options.text: Lower trunk of the brachial plexus

options.label: C
options.text: Upper trunk of the brachial plexus

questions.correct_answer: C. Upper trunk of the brachial plexus
questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Anatomical Role

Upper trunk divides into anterior and posterior divisions

Clinical Importance

Injuries to this area can cause Erb's palsy with specific motor/sensory deficits

Erb's Palsy

Results from damage to the upper trunk, leading to weakness in the upper limb, waiter-tip posture.

questions.text: A newborn presents with weakness in the right arm after a difficult vaginal delivery. The arm is limp and hangs by the side, with the forearm pronated and the hand facing inward in a "waiter's tip" position. The infant has difficulty with shoulder abduction and elbow flexion. Which of the following nerve roots are most likely involved in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Structure

Description

Brachial Plexus

Formed by ventral rami of C5-T1 spinal nerves

Upper Trunk

Union of C5 and C6 ventral rami

Erb’s Point

Located in the posterior triangle of the neck, where the upper trunk divides into anterior and posterior divisions

Condition

Description

Horner's Syndrome

Involvement of T1 nerve root, indicating a more extensive injury

Skeletal Abnormalities

Bone deformities (e.g., glenoid dysplasia, clavicular shortening) due to muscle imbalance

questions.text: A newborn presents with weakness in the hand following a difficult delivery. Examination reveals a claw hand deformity characterized by hyperextension at the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion at the interphalangeal joints. Sensory loss is noted along the ulnar aspect of the forearm and hand. Which of the following is the most likely nerve root involved in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Site of Injury

Lower trunk of the brachial plexus

Cause of Injury

Undue arm abduction (e.g., clutching after a fall)

Birth injury

Nerve Roots Involved

Primarily T1, partially C8

questions.text: Which of the following gives rise to the bones and connective tissues of the limb?

options.label: B
options.text: The parietal (somatic) layer of lateral plate mesoderm

questions.correct_answer: B. The parietal (somatic) layer of lateral plate mesoderm
questions.explanation:
Period of Gestation

Event

4th Week

Appearance of the upper limb bud

6th Week

Formation of hand plate and initiation of chondrification.

7th Week

Limb rotation and further cartilage development.

12th Week

Primary ossification centers in long bones.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with numbness and tingling along the lateral aspect of his forearm and thumb following a fall on his outstretched arm. Which dermatome is most likely involved?
questions.explanation:
Spinal Nerve Root

Dermatome (Sensory Area)

C5 (Option A ruled out)

Lateral upper arm, over the deltoid

C6 (Option B)

Lateral forearm and thumb(1st digit)

C7 (Option C ruled out)

Index finger (2nd digit) to Ring finger (4th digit)

C8 (Option D ruled out)

Medial forearm, little finger (5th digit)

T1

Medial arm and elbow

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with difficulty extending his elbow after a recent injury. On examination, you notice weakness in elbow extension and diminished triceps reflex. Sensory examination is normal. Which myotome is most likely affected?
questions.explanation:
Spinal Nerve Root

Myotome (Motor Function)

C5 (Option A ruled out)

Shoulder abduction (deltoid), elbow flexion (biceps)

C6 (Option B ruled out)

Elbow flexion, wrist extension (biceps, wrist extensors)

C7 (Option C)

Elbow extension (triceps), wrist flexion (wrist flexors)

C8 (Option D ruled out)

Finger flexion, thumb extension (finger flexors, intrinsic hand muscles)

T1

Finger abduction and adduction (intrinsic hand muscles, interossei)

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with weakness in the upper limb following a fall on his shoulder. Physical examination reveals impaired movement in the extensor muscles of the arm. Injury to which part of the brachial plexus is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Trunk

Formation

Divisions

Upper Trunk

Union of C5 and C6 rami

Anterior: Flexor muscles (Option A ruled out)

Posterior: Extensor muscles

Middle Trunk


 

Continuation of C7

Anterior: Flexor muscles (Option B ruled out)

Posterior: Extensor muscles (Option C)

Lower Trunk

Union of C8 and T1 rami

Anterior: Flexor muscles (Option A ruled out)

Passing over first rib

Posterior: Extensor muscles

questions.text: A 25-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a high-speed motorcycle accident. He complains of severe pain and weakness in his right arm. On examination, there is loss of sensation in the right shoulder and upper arm with weakness in shoulder abduction and elbow flexion. Which of the following is the most likely type of brachial plexus lesion in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Closed Traction Lesions (Option C)

Result from forces that stretch or tear nerves, often in high-impact incidents like accidents.

Intradural Ruptures/Avulsions (Option A ruled out)

Nerve roots torn from the spinal cord; harder to treat than other injuries.

Compression Injuries (Option B ruled out)

Caused by pressure on the brachial plexus, including:

Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (TOS): Compression between the clavicle and first rib.

Hematoma: Internal bleeding compressing the plexus.

Anomalous Muscles/Structures: Extra anatomical features causing compression.

Iatrogenic Injury: Damage during medical procedures. (Option D ruled out)

Symptom

Description

Sensory Changes

Numbness, tingling, pain, or burning in the shoulder, arm, or hand.

Motor Weakness

Difficulty moving the shoulder, arm, or hand, with specific weakness patterns aiding localization.

Autonomic Dysfunction

Changes in sweating, skin temperature, or blood flow in the affected limb.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with weakness in elbow flexion and loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of his forearm. Which of the following nerves is most likely involved in this patient’s condition?
questions.explanation:
Cord

Formation

Lateral Cord

Anterior divisions of upper and middle trunks

Posterior Cord

All three posterior divisions

Medial Cord

Anterior division of lower trunk (sometimes middle trunk)

Cord

Nerve

Motor Innervation

Sensory Innervation

Lateral Cord

Musculocutaneous (C5, C6, C7) (Option B)

Biceps brachii, brachialis, coracobrachialis

Lateral forearm

Lateral Root of Median (C5, C6, C7)

Contributes to median nerve (primarily hand muscles)

Contributes to sensory innervation of the hand

Posterior Cord

Axillary (C5, C6) (Option A ruled out)

Deltoid, teres minor

Lateral shoulder

Radial (C5, C6, C7, C8, T1) (Option C ruled out)

Triceps, brachioradialis, wrist and finger extensors, supinator

Posterior arm, forearm, dorsolateral hand

Upper Subscapular (C5, C6)

Subscapularis

None

Thoracodorsal (C6, C7, C8)

Latissimus dorsi

None

Lower Subscapular (C5, C6)

Subscapularis, teres major

None

Medial Cord

Ulnar (C8, T1) (Option D ruled out)

Flexor carpi ulnaris, flexor digitorum profundus (medial half), most intrinsic hand muscles

Medial hand, little finger, medial half of ring finger

Median (C5, C6, C7, C8, T1)

Pronators, wrist/finger flexors (except those supplied by ulnar), thenar muscles

Palmar hand (thumb, index, middle, lateral half of ring finger)

Medial Pectoral (C8, T1)

Pectoralis major, pectoralis minor

None

Medial Cutaneous Nerve of Arm (C8, T1)

None

Medial arm

Medial Cutaneous Nerve of Forearm (C8, T1)

None

Medial forearm

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the variations in the prefixed and postfixed brachial plexus?

options.label: A
options.text: Prefixed brachial plexus is characterized by contributions from C5 to T2.

options.label: B
options.text: T2 spinal nerve replaces the usual T1 contribution in postfixed brachial plexus.

options.label: C
options.text: Prefixed brachial plexus has an increased contribution from C4 and decreased from T1.

options.label: D
options.text: Postfixed brachial plexus is associated with an increased contribution from C3 and C4.

questions.correct_answer: C. Prefixed brachial plexus has an increased contribution from C4 and decreased from T1.
questions.explanation:
Prefixed

Postfixed

Nerve root

C4-C8

C6-T2

Shift

Upward shift

Downward shift

C4 contribution

Increased

Nil or minimal

C5 contribution

Normal

Reduced

T1 contribution

Reduced or nil

Normal along with added T2

Risk

No risk of compression

High risk of compression

(Thoracic outlet syndrome)

questions.text: Which part of the brachial plexus does not give off any branches?
questions.explanation:
Part of brachial plexus

Branches

Roots
  • Dorsal scapular nerve - C5
  • Long thoracic nerve - C5 to C7

Trunks
  • Suprascapular nerve - C5, C6
  • Nerve to subclavius - C5, C6

Division
  • None

Cords
  • Lateral pectoral nerve (Lateral cord: C5-C7)
  • Upper subscapular nerve (Posterior cord: C5, C6)
  • Thoracodorsal nerve (Posterior cord: C6-C8)
  • Lower subscapular nerve (Posterior cord: C5, C6)
  • Medial pectoral nerve (Medial cord: C8, T1)
  • Medial cutaneous nerve of arm (Medial cord: C8, T1)
  • Medial cutaneous nerve of forearm (Medial cord: C8, T1)

Terminal branches
  • Musculocutaneous nerve (Lateral cord, C5-C7)
  • Axillary nerve (Posterior cord, C5, C6)
  • Radial nerve (Posterior cord, C5-T1)
  • Median nerve (Lateral and Medial cords, C5-T1)
  • Ulnar nerve (Medial cord, C8, T1)

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the anterior and posterior axial lines is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Axial lines form as a result of limb rotational and elongation processes during embryogenesis

options.label: B
options.text: Axial lines divide dermatomes that are adjacent in the spinal nerve sequence

options.label: C
options.text: Overlapping of nerve supply can overlap across axial lines

options.label: D
options.text: Overlapping of Ventral and dorsal axial lines can occur

questions.correct_answer: A. Axial lines form as a result of limb rotational and elongation processes during embryogenesis
questions.explanation:
Axial lines

Axial lines are the dividing lines between dermatomes that are not adjacent in the spinal nerve sequence.

Types

  • Ventral Axial Line (on the anterior surface of the limb).
  • Dorsal Axial Line (on the posterior surface of the limb).

Formation

  • During embryological development, the limbs undergo lateral rotation (upper limb) or medial rotation (lower limb).
  • This rotation creates a spiral arrangement of dermatomes and shifts certain dermatomes distally.
  • Axial lines form as a result of these rotational and elongation processes.

Significance

  • Axial lines are important for understanding nerve injuries and mapping sensory deficits.
  • Across these lines, there is no overlap between dermatomes, so sensory loss in these areas can help pinpoint the exact nerve or spinal segment involved.
